Monitoring with an SPC Control Chart & Run Rules 

Link to Organizer Topic

All

Objective

Production teams need a uniform way to interpret process, quality, and equipment data to determine when a process is out of control and requires intervention. Using statistical methodologies, such as creating control charts and applying run rules, helps production teams better understand the data and apply a uniform approach to data analysis.

Analysis Steps:

Starting Point

 

Check for Normalcy

Step 1: Create a condition for each time the grade code changes using the formula function .tocondition(). (workstep)

Step 2: Create a histogram 'binned' by grade code to determine whether the data is normal. ()

 

Identify In-Control Periods

Step 3: Choose a time after start-up where the process is considered in-control for each grade. Use Manual Condition to pick these periods of time. (

 

Calculate Control Limits

Step 4: Calculate mean and standard deviation using the In-Control condition and apply to all grades using the formula tool and splice() function. (

Step 5: Using formula, create the control limits (:

  • +/- 1 Std Dev Limits +1 Sigma, -1 Sigma (
  • +/- 2 Std Dev Limits +2 Sigma, -2 Sigma (
  • +/- 3 Std Dev Limits +3 Sigma, -3 Sigma (

 

Create Run Rules

Here we will use the Nelson Run Rules, but you could also use Western Electric Run Rules.

 

Step 6: Use Seeq formula to create run rules. (

Step 7: Combine all run rules into one condition and set Property 'Run Rule'. Step to current time to monitor the ongoing run. (

Step 8:  View the run rule violations in a table sorted descending by start date. (

 

Monitoring View

Table View
